stream.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a natural flow of water that moves across the land and is narrower than a river
stream.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a long and almost continuous series of events, people, objects etc
stream.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: A steady stream of visitors came to the house.
stream.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a flow of water, air, smoke etc, or the direction in which it is flowing
stream.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: A stream of cold air rushed through the open door.
stream.translation[0].definitions[3].def: a level of ability within a group of students of the same age
stream.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to flow quickly and in great amounts
stream.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Water came streaming out of the burst pipe.
stream.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to move in a continuous flow in the same direction
stream.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: People streamed past us on all sides.
stream.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to produce a continuous flow of liquid
stream.translation[1].definitions[2].not: streaming cold British English (=an illness in which a lot of liquid comes out of your nose)
stream.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: When I got up, my face was streaming with blood.
stream.translation[1].definitions[3].def: if light streams somewhere, it shines through an opening into a place or onto a surface
stream.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: The first rays of morning sunlight streamed through the open doorway.
stream.translation[1].definitions[4].typ: intransitive always + adverb/preposition, usually in progressive
stream.translation[1].definitions[4].def: to move freely in a current of wind or water
stream.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: Elise ran, her hair streaming out behind her.
stream.translation[1].definitions[5].def: if you stream sound or video, you play it on your computer while it is being downloaded from the Internet, rather than saving it as a file and then playing it
stream.translation[1].definitions[6].def: to put school children in groups according to their ability
stream.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a long and almost continuous series of things
stream.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Despite the steady stream of layoffs, federal statisticians are predicting growth in select industries.
The refinery will come on stream (=start producing a stream of oil) next year.
stream.translation[2].definitions[1].def: regular amounts of money coming into a company or organization from a particular activity or source, especially over a long period of time
stream.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: The city will get an income stream from property and income taxes paid by the new owners.
The new products account for more than 80% of the company’s revenue stream.
